Award.AwardTitle: Digitization TCN: Collaborative: Documenting Fossil Marine Invertebrate Communities of the Eastern Pacific - Faunal Responses to Environmental Change over the last 66 million years
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fossils provide our only direct evidence of past biodiversity and how individual organisms to ecosystems have responded to past and long-term environmental change. This project fills a major gap in the documentation of past environmental change, making available digitized data from the especially rich fossil record of the eastern Pacific marine invertebrate communities of the Cenozoic, the 66 million years that have passed since the extinction of the dinosaurs. Digitization and integration of these data will foster increased accessibility, efficient analysis to understand past change, the identification of factors involved in that change, and enable predictions for how current biodiversity may be impacted by future change. Development of virtual fieldwork experiences will assist stakeholders and educators in understanding how field data and fossil collections are used to infer past ecosystem and environmental conditions.

The data currently exist as a vast collection of fossil specimens and printed materials distributed among multiple natural history collections: this project involves 7 primary institutions, one small collection and one federal institution and will integrate this digitized specimen data with the other two ongoing fossil networks through the web portal iDigPaleo, expanding the resource for fossil invertebrate information by spanning over 500 million years. This wealth of data will provide resources not only to researchers, but will be made available to K-16 educators, government, industry, and the general public. Through the national resource (iDigBio) these data will be integrated with information on modern organisms providing the means to understand important questions on niches, environmental change, transitions in sea levels, etc. Additionally, undergraduate and graduate students will be trained in the modern uses of natural history collections. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The fossil record provides the only direct window into long term ecological and environmental changes. At this time of unprecedented species extinctions tied to global environmental degradation, paleontological studies can proved the scientific basis for efforts to combat both these potential disasters to humankind. This digitization TCN allowed us at the Burke Museum of Natural History at the  University of Washington to record all the marine fossils, 66 million years and younger, and to make them available to both academia and the general public for future studies. The project targeted marine invertebrates from sites along the eastern Pacific margin, from Alaska to Chile. In the Burke’s paleontological collections, the biggest component of these are from Washington State and they had not been accessible before. We digitized over 100,000 fossil specimens from 8,400 different collecting localities. These exceed our stated goals. This data gathering also involved updating species names and higher level taxonomic information associated with every specimen. Attached to the data are 700 photos of the most exemplary or rare specimens. Fossils from Washington State have been impacted by millions of years of plate tectonic activity and rendered many of them less than exemplary in appearance. 

This TCN project has a significant impact on the Paleontologic Division of the Burke Museum by hiring a project manager as well as graduate and undergraduate students to work on the digitization of fossils, photography and geo-referencing of localities each academic year. The students learned organizational skills, curatorial techniques, best practices for museums, the ethics of collecting and an appreciation of what a museum provides to their local and broader communities.

The data assembled of marine fossil faunas by this TCN complements the similar digitization projects form Gulf Coast and Atlantic faunas. These can provide a larger understanding of the impact of natural, more geologically-timed climate changes in the past.

 


Last Modified: 10/16/2020
Modified by: Elizabeth A Nesbitt
